turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: There she is! You'll find Joan Gale in that box.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: No -- No -- I -- I -- I don't want to see it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: You go in for dangerous things.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Darned if I don't!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: --and so determined to live that I'm going to get out and take a taxi if you don't watch where you're going.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: I suppose this is going to sound absurd. I've only known you twenty-four hours, but I'm in love with you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: It doesn't usually take that long, but I'll forgive you -- you were in a tough spot when I met you.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: No, really -- I'm crazy about you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Oh, is that what caused it?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: You don't believe me. You think I'm just talking. Will you marry me?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: How much money have you got?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Heaven knows. A lot.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, that being the case, I'll take it up with the board of directors. Hey, listen, aviator, here we are!

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: What is it? What happened?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Don't ask any questions. Come on!

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You are too gracious. These things have some merit, I suspect ... but this--  ... I am convinced, is fine.

turns.speaker: GOLATILY
turns.text: Even those delicate veins, the texture of this flesh -- I have never seen anything more exquisite.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: My partner believes that I should build a horror chamber, immortalizing the hideous crimes and criminals of London. At such times Marie Antoinette has reassured me, she has promised me recognition for the devotion I gave to her.

turns.speaker: GOLATILY
turns.text: She will undoubtedly keep her promise. If you'll grant me the privilege, I'd like to submit this work to the Royal Academy when I get back.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You will have won the undying gratitude of us all.  Is that not so, Marie Antoinette?

turns.speaker: GOLATILY
turns.text: I regret I can't spend the time I'd like with your exhibition, but I'm going to worry the life out of you when I come back.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: It will always afford me great pleasure to see you.

turns.speaker: GOLATILY
turns.text: Good night, sir.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Good night.  And I am very grateful to you.

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: I came back for some of the books. I am trying to straighten out the accounts. I don't hope to impress you, but I may as well tell you: We haven't a farthing!

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: That is unfortunate.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Your money may have been well invested, my friend. Something important may come of all this.

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: Something important has got to come of it! Do you know that the rent on this place isn't paid?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Is that a fact?

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: No -- I'm lying to amuse myself!  Now look here, I've an idea that will get us out of all this. We haven't twopence between us, but we've got these.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Fire insurance!

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: Yes, there's our way out. A fire in this place would give us ten thousand pounds.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: A fire! Is this your idea of humor, my friend?

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: I want the money back I've thrown into this rubbish heap.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You are asking to burn these people ... you are asking? ...

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: I'm not asking you anything. I'm telling you what I'm going to do!

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: And you think I will permit this, my friend?

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: You've got to permit it! Whose fault is it that no one comes here? The museum at Walston Lane does well enough, and why? They've got Jack the Ripper, Burke and Hare, the Mad Butcher, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street and things people pay to see.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: And they are welcome to them. To perpetuate such creatures is to celebrate their crimes.

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: Well, what do you think I'm in this for?  Think of it, man, a match -- a cigar stub -- and ten thousand pounds to divide between us!

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You're insane.

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: Not at all -- let me show you how easily it can be done.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: If my curiosity is not too great, would you mind telling me what manner of animal this is you are designing?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: One of the maids-in-waiting for that Elizabethan group.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: And he isn't struck dead! This man, he lives! It would be interesting to know, young man, where and when you studied anatomy.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: That doesn't seem so bad to me. What is wrong with it?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Everything, my friend. And you hope to be a great sculptor --  A great sculptor. Look -- this forearm is at least two inches too long.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: But the composition as a whole -- I've tried to keep a sketchy freedom.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: If it is freedom to represent people with limbs that don't match -- cripples -- you have achieved your purpose. Anatomy! Heaven forgive you. You must have studied with a sideshow of freaks!

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: To lunch.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: To lunch, you say. I am having coffee and sandwiches sent in. We are not leaving until we have everything ready for the opening.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: But I have some friends waiting.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: That is unfortunate. They will have to wait.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: I will only be gone about half an hour.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: If you leave before the work is done, you will be gone for a much longer period ... you will be gone for good.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: All right, I'll tell them. They're right here in front.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: I wouldn't feel too disappointed at the slimness of your audience tonight, Mr. Igor. The weather was against you, and the people are tired and getting over their celebration and preparing to go to work tomorrow.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Quite so. Quite so.  And you, my little friend, my little Marie Antoinette. It is kind of you to be present.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Have you got it? Is it completed?

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: Yes, sir, it's here on the truck, but it's pretty heavy -- I'll need help.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Otto! You and one of those other fellows! Come help Professor Darcey.

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: Shall we unpack it?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: I'd be glad to, Mr. Igor.  I think I'll have somethin' to tell you soon.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You have done well, and now I, too, have something for you. Come.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: She is the soul of that statue.

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: I wonder if I could have her pose for me.

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: What are you laughing at?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: He can't hear you.

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: I'd know him anywhere.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Don't lose sight of him. This is the most important thing in my life.

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: Yep. Everything settled.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Good. Well, I'll be seeing you.

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: I'm glad they didn't hold you downtown.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: They didn't have a leg to stand on. There's no case against me. It's a clumsy thing to have happen, but nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: WORTH
turns.text: Well, any time I can do anything for you --

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: To isolation.  To an armed camp.  To a biblical spoof of a crazed father firing a gun at his only son.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: You taking any medication?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Don't waste it Pauly.  This is not an everyday talk.  Just input the information and ask relevant questions.  One: how did a celebrated life of the mind bring me  to this particular switching station?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Dad...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Two: what if I didn't miss?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: You did.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Spare me your classical answer. Measurements in.  Results taken.  What if I didn't miss?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: You did miss --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: -- What if your seven and a half precious liters were downloading over the parquet floor?  What then?   What did your life mean?  Who did you nurture, Pauly?  Who did you love?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What was her name?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Excuse me???

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What was her name?  The one I met.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Mia...?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes....

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: I've been dreaming about you.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: Day or night?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Could we go somewhere?

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: I'm heading out of town.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: I could go out of town.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: Could you?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Where to?

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: A place you've never been.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: That's the physicist's playground.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: Why am I doing this?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: It's an experiment.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: We flopped the first time out.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: At the sub-atomic level, particles obey their own logic.  They connect in unimaginable ways.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Could be.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: What universe are you in, Paul?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: A quantum one.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Nothing is real until it's perceived.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: The Buddhists have been saying that for a millennium.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: Of what?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: God.  I dunno.  The eternal nothingness. Mia.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: What did it want?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: That's what it asked me.  "What do you want?"  I didn't answer.  I was in the middle of an experiment.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: Like now?

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: No.  I didn't.   I'm listening.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Inside every semi-conductor... you have two particles, with opposite charges, separated by an impassable barrier...

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: She's in L.A., he's in the Bay area --

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: A five hundred foot thick steel wall.  But the connection between these two electrons is so --

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: Dysfunctional --

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: That they tunnel, magically, through any obstacle, defying the practical laws of physics, in order to end up together --

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: And glow happily ever after.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: I didn't want to leave things the way we did.  Not this time.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Wait.  I want to tell you something.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: I've been dreaming about this.

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Then you get it.  You'll understand.

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PENTCHO
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MIA
turns.text: So I can move on.  You too.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Is Rose here?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She must have gone out for a walk with the children.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Well, I got to see her.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She isn't here. And I'm sorry, but Mr. Hillyer doesn't want her to have callers during working hours.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Where is she?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I said she isn't here. NOW you go home. Be a nice boy and go home.

turns.speaker: BROTHER
turns.text: They're filthy, Mother.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Sex isn't ugly, sex is one of the most beautiful things in life, the creative power of the universe is behind it.

turns.speaker: BROTHER
turns.text: I know, Mother.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But we must respect that power, we must be in awe of it.

turns.speaker: BROTHER
turns.text: I am in awe of it, Mother.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I don't think you are sufficiently in awe of it. Get the castor oil.

turns.speaker: BROTHER
turns.text: Oh, Mother, not the castor oil.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: This isn't punishment, I don't believe in punishment. It's for your health. Obviously you're sick if you can act like that.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Lots of things. Buddy, mostly.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy. Well, now, that's a nice name, I like it. I am real pleased to meet you.  Hey, look, do you think you got a cold drink of ice water somewhere?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Sure. Let me take your suitcase.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, who were those scoundrels in Birmingham?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Nobody.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: But who were they?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: They were just bad men, that's all.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: In what sense were they bad?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Bad is bad, Buddy. There ain't no sense to it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Did they try to induce you to become a prostitute?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Was that what they tried to do? Was that why Daddy gave you the job, to save you from those scoundrels?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Your Daddy is a wonderful man, I'll say that. He's the best and most kind-hearted man in the world.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Hey, Rose, did you hear about that terrible thing down in Cave Springs?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: What terrible thing in Cave Springs?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: There was this old man that ate his niece.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I didn't hear you. I didn't hear that.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: He really did, he ate his little niece. He made pork chops out of her.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I don't hear you. I just turn my back on that kind of talk and look away.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, it's only the truth. There are horrible things in the world, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, you are in one of your evil moods, I don't want to talk to you. I'm going out and sweep the patio.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: No, I'm awake. What's the matter?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, I am wandering in a wilderness, lost.  I just feel awful. Do you mind if I get in bed with you for a little while?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, all right.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I thought I'd go crazy back there in that room all by myself with nobody to talk to. As a child, I never had no room all to myself, we were awful poor. Buddy... I have got a confession to make.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What is it, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: It's so terrible I can't tell you. Oh, Buddy, you don't know how it hurts to have a broken heart, what a terrible feeling it is, and I've had a broken heart so many times. Men, I don't understand them, I can't figure them out and they break my heart, that's all. I can't find Mr. Right, Buddy, I can't find him no matter how hard I look, all I find is a whole pile of Mr. Wrongs. But this is the worst ever because it wasn't his fault. It was my fault, oh yes, my fault, I was bad -- oh God, I was bad, you wouldn't believe how bad I was.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What'd you do, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, I was horrible. I can't tell you who it was, but do you know what I did? I sat on his lap and got ahold of him and wiggled and wiggled my ass on him and was worse'n you could know, a child like you. Why, I let one of my tits fall out deliberate on purpose and practically smack him in the face with it and I let my dern skirt come up so he could see my drawers...  But to get back serious to what I was sayin', it is not only, Buddy, the loss of him but my own bad behavior what bothers me so...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: You were pretty bad, huh?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Why, it has just made me ill, Buddy. I'm sick. I don't want to eat nothin', I don't, and me I got a good appetite, that ain't nat'ral for me. I'm ill.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: But, Rose, what is the cause of it all?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Promise not to tell Doll? -- or nobody? Buddy, it's your Daddy! I'm so much in love with him I am out of my mind!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: But, Rose, how could such a thing as that happen?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I fell madly in love with him when he called me Rosebud. You know that first day when I come and he said I looked graceful like a capital letter S and called me Rosebud? I fell madly in love with that man right then.  But it's a lost love, Buddy. He's a good man and won't have nothin' to do with me.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Hmmm, it's soft. It's awful soft.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: What did you expect?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, I thought they were more like a cantaloupe.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Ha ha ha, that's some idea, a cantaloupe.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: There's some kind of gristle in it, though.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, quit that, you're just a child, you're not supposed to be interested in such things.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Actually, I am, though.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You know, that Daddy of yours is the funniest man, the things he says, you never know what's going to come out of his mouth next.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Can I put my hand inside your nightgown, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No, you can't. And I'll tell you this -- he scares me. As kind as he is, he scares me. You can't fool around with him, not with that man. And, boy, I sure better not try nothin' like that with him again, he'll fire me.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, can't I see what the nipple on it is like?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, what's come over you? A child like you, askin' such things.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: But I'm curious, Rose.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Just for a second. Please, Rose, what's the harm?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, you don't realize it but what you're doing isn't nice.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Aw, come on, Rose, I want to see what the nipple on it is like.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You don' t need to know that. It's none of your business.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Aw, be a good sport, Rose.  You like me, don't you? I like you a lot.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, are you satisfied now? Can we just lie and talk, huh?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Hmmph. It has a nipple, all right.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: 'Course it does.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: First I couldn't feel it, but now I feel it easily, it's like a little acorn.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: All right, that's enough.  You're just a child and wouldn't understand it, but that type of thing can stir a girl up. Now lie back and we'll talk.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: That was very interesting. Thank you, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Don't mention it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: It was softer'n I thought, that was my main impression. You know, if you hit a girl there it would hurt her a lot.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Who would want to do such a thing as that?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, some fiend might.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You know, Buddy, sometimes I can't figure you out at all. You can be very nice, but like your mother said there's an evil streak in you.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: There's an evil streak in everybody, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: There ain't none in your Daddy. You know, what happened has just made me love him all the more. I not only love him, I respect him, I admire him.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, I have a serious favor to ask you.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Most men wouldn't do what he done. If they can get a girl they go right ahead and get her -- I guess to hell they do, just like a dern rabbit. 'Course later they'll tell her she's no good when they done the same thing their selves. They're a bunch of monkeys. I like 'em, but they're a bunch of monkeys.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, since you're here in bed with me and everything and I've already touched your titty...

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Why, Buddy, shut your mouth! What an awful thing to say, and where did you get any such idea as that, anyhow?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I'm curious to see what it's like. I'm very curious, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, now that is just too bad! Curiosity killed the cat.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yeah, but satisfaction brought him back. Can I?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No! You ought to be ashamed of yourself astin' such a nasty things a child your age!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Can't I touch it a little, Rose -- not a lot, just a little?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Of course you can't! I'm... I'm shocked at you, Buddy, real shocked! Now you be quiet or I'm going back to my own bed!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Please, Rose. I'm curious, that's all, I have a natural curiosity, it's only human. You're my friend, aren't you? Don't you like me?  I like you, Rose, a lot -- in fact, I love you.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, you're sweet, but you don't really love me.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yes, I do. Please, Rose, be a good sport.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, you're just a child.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I'm thirteen. And I have a natural curiosity. It's only nature, Rose, that's all. Now what's wrong with nature, huh?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, nothin'.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You better quit that.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: But Rose...

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I must be outta my mind. Buddy, quit it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Am I hurting you?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No. No, you're not hurting me.  But I think you better quit it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: But why, if I'm not hurting you?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You wouldn't understand.  Oh, God, I must be outta my mind. What would your Momma think?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, are you all right? Are you sick or something?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No. No, I'm all right.  Oh, God, what have I done? I have robbed a cradle and fallen into hell!  I must be crazy, a child like you. Oh, God, oh, Lord. This is awful, this is terrible, I gotta get outta here!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, you wouldn't tell nobody, would you?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Don't worry, Rose, I won't tell a soul.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I sure hope you don't.  I gotta get outta here, good night.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Good night, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I hate to turn on this light, you Daddy's awake downstairs, but I have to take the chance.  Buddy, please don't tell on me.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I said I wouldn't.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, I have to ask you, as bad as I've been please have pity on me and don't ruin me by telling them what I did. I know it was bad, it was bad and dumb. But mostly it was dumb, I didn't mean you no harm, I'd never want to hurt a hair on your head and that's the truth. I love you. But they'd think I did, they'd think I was awful, they'd despise me and hate me...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, they could stick splinters under my fingernails, and I will never say a word! I will never tell them, because... I love you!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, Buddy, you do love me! I knew you did, knew it all the time...

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, Ill tell you this. I have learned a lesson tonight. I wasn't gonna run around, but when I start botherin' your Daddy and worse robbin' a cradle, I gotta face the facts of life.  Tomorrow mornin', I'm gonna get myself up and go out.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: You're going to get yourself up and go out?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, Mr. Right is out there somewhere and I'm gonna find him!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Here comes Daddy.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I have a knack for designing clothes. But I had to buy the shoes and the pocketbook.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Did your Momma really give you castor oil?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You're my sweetheart.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, you must know who the fellow is.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, he might be that man who followed me home from the store the other day. But I don't know who he is, Buddy, I really don't.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I got an awful toothache.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, if you don't keep your boyfriends away from the house, Daddy is going to fire you.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: But I don't know who they are.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, he's so kind, so gentle inside, and so unhappy with that rich wife who doesn't understand him, her being a Southerner and everything, and what a bedside manner he has got -- so gentle and kind beneath the professor way he acts!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, you are too uncritical of people.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You don't know the bedside manner that man has got. Why, it does me good just to see him sit there all solemn and go pokin' in his bag like he's gonna cure me, which he did of course. And even more important he loves me, like a patient I mean, the other day he got tears in his eyes just listenin' to my heart beat.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: He did?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yeah, he tried to hide it but I saw 'em, and a little bit he says to me, "You know, you are beautiful." Now wasn't that a nice thing for a doctor to say to a patient, wasn't it? What could cheer a girl up more?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, I have got doubts about that doctor and so does Daddy.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: He's got doubts about hisself and that's the saddest thing of all. Would you believe that poor man thinks nobody likes him?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yeah, I'd believe it.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, I like him. I used to be afraid of doctors but not any more. Why, he could operate on me any old time and I wouldn't even be scared.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose, you are just entirely too uncritical of people.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I ain't neither. Listen here, Buddy, besides all his vast medical knowledge, he has the most kindest heart beneath the professor way he acts -- he wants justice in the world and he's got some real interestin' ideas.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, Buddy, they're gonna cut me all up! They're gonna cut my stummick all open, I'll die!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: You won't die, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, I'm scared, I'm scared!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I gotta find out what they're saying. You lie back and rest, Rose, and I'll give you a report on it.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I don't want to know...

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Hi, Buddy.  How's my sweetheart who never told on me when I was bad?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Makin' homes for purple martins, huh? We had 'em on the farm. They're the prettiest things. That's what I wish I was, a bird. Just fly around catch bugs and have a lot of fun.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What are you going to do, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Take a little walk with me, huh?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I guess I'll work as a waitress, Buddy. I done that before and it got me in worse trouble than you could know, but I can't stay here no more. Why did you get rid of your rabbits, Buddy?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: They're dumb things. I got tired of them.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Did you know when I was a child we had pretty near five hundred rabbits?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Five hundred rabbits?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yep, we had 'em in orange crates all over. It was Daddy's dream. He was goin' to get rich raisin' rabbits. It was what killed Daddy. He didn't drown hisself till a long time later after Momma and Lunette died of typhoid, but it was them rabbits what killed him.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: How did the rabbits kill him?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: He thought he could sell 'em, but nobody but country folks eat rabbits, Buddy, and they ain't got no money. We had to eat them dern rabbits our own selves. Every dern one, and it took about four years to eat 'em all up.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, that doctor said you got protein somewhere and I guess he was right.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Boy did I get sick of rabbit. But later on after Momma died and Daddy wasn't doin' nothin' but drinkin', I sure would of been glad for a little rabbit stew. You know, I oughtn't to of told you about what Daddy done when I was a child. Until them rabbits ruined him, he was a real good man, Buddy.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What was your mother like?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: A saint just like your own mother. She's up in heaven right now, her and Lunette, there ain't no doubt about it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Maybe it was eating all those rabbits that made you sexy, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Buddy, sex don't mean a thing to me. It ain't nothin' but a mosquito bite.  I'll tell you a secret. Girls don't want sex, Buddy, girls want love.

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: Neither do I.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Oh, Waski, you don't even know what we're talking about.

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: I do, too.

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: Yeah, I know.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Oh, Waski, you don't know anything.

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: I do, too!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: All right, what do you know?

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: Rose is madly in love with Daddy...

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: He did lie, and... and... and Mother, yesterday he stole money out of your pocketbook!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Quiet, you little muddy-eyed brat, or Ill kill you!

turns.speaker: WASKI
turns.text: Of course not!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Oh, Waski, you don't even know what we're talking about.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You were up late last night, Brother.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, a little.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Reading dirty comic bocks.  And you admitted it?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, yeah.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Son, was Rose in your room last night?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: No. Why should Rose be in my room?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I never saw anything like it. How did she pick him up so fast?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: The girl strikes like a cobra.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Is that Doctor still up there, Brother.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yeah, he's still up there.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: What's taking the rascal so long?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: What do you think, Brother?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I don't know. But you better watch him like a hawk, if he comes back again.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: He's not coming back again. We scared the rascal off, son.  Come on back to supper. Your mother has a theory about how to educate Rose.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: See that, son? Now this is a heel, see, and there, that's the ball of a foot. Someone has been walking here.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, it's not very plain.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: That is because it rained recently, the rain has obscured the evidence. But you could still take plaster casts of these footprints, then match up the plaster casts with whosever shoes they are, and that way you could catch him -- understand?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: But how would you find him?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well. Well, what I mean is, you could prove it was his shoes if you did catch him. But look this, Brother, it is even more interesting. Look at this mark here, and that mark over there. Now wouldn't you say those marks are the marks of a ladder?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well, I don't know.  No, I don't know, Daddy, I think the rain has obscured it.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: True, but if you look sharply you can see that those marks are the marks of a ladder. Now let's go back to the garage and see if the ladder has been tampered with.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: See, son? The paint is flaked off here, freshly. Look at it, Brother, there is no question about it. Some person or persons unknown have very recently tampered with this ladder.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Well... maybe...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: And there's only one reason anybody would want this ladder -- to get up into Rose's bedroom in the dark of night! I am going to chain up this ladder and padlock it! -- and that is not all I am going to do!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Open that door, damn you!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Daddy, what's the matter?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: She's got somebody in there, Brother! His shoes are on the back porch -- there they were, naked and smiling at me!  Rose, open this door immediately!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I heard you talking. Hasn't Rose come in?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No, she hasn't.  I think I hear a car.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: The new girl is here.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Wonderful. What's she like, Brother? What is your impression of her?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: She talks a great deal and smiles a lot. She's very pretty, she has a real good figure. She's very girlish or womanish, if you know what I mean. She wouldn't hurt anybody, this girl. She couldn't.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Your impression is very reassuring, Brother. Of course she's had troubles, poor thing, but I sensed that was that the girl was like and I'm glad to have it reconfirmed.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: You mean confirmed, Mother. I didn't confirm it before. I would have had to confirm it previously, in order for it to be reconfirmed.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: All right, all right. Doll and Waski are upstairs taking their nap, you go get them and bring them down to the living room. Where is the girl?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: In the kitchen drinking all the ice water in Glenville. She walked out here, she didn't go by the hotel.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Walked, in all that heat? It's a wonder she hasn't got sunstroke. I'll phone Daddy and you go get Doll Baby and Waski.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Brother, when I have to wake you up at eleven o'clock in the morning you're either sick or you were up very late last night.  And you weren't reading Huckleberry Finn. I looked and its not in your room. Now what were you doing?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Mother, I have to tell the truth. I wasn't reading Huckleberry Finn, I was reading one of those Little Dirty Comic Books.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh, Brother, I am so disappointed in you. You mustn't look at those horrible things, they degrade the human image.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Mother, cant you make it calomel instead of castor oil?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: This is for your own good. When you look at negative, destructive things like those little filthy comic books, you are sick. Here, take this.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Geccch, yehh, guhhhh!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Stop gagging like that and putting on a show, and swallow it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Uhhh, gahdam stuff!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What did you say, Brother?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I said ahhh-dam stuff.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: No, you didn't say that, Brother.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yes, I did, mother. Your hearing aid isn't working right. I said ahhh-dam stuff.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Children, children! Be quiet, all of you!  The vibrations in this house are strange today. Where's Rose, anyhow?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: She's getting herself up to go out.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What'd you say, Brother?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: She's getting herself up to go out. I think she's coming down the hall now.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh, yes, it's Thursday.  Hello, Rose, dear...  ... my, you're... looking pretty...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Heh, what a hypocrite.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I do wish you'd speak to Brother. It's true he's been looking at those horrible little books again.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Excuse me, gotta go to bathroom.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Now I have a plan about Rose, an educational plan. She's getting better and we don't want any more trouble --  Brother, you ought to hear this.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose is almost as sentimental as Mother. If there's one thing I can't stand it's sentimentality. In Chattanooga this man committed an almost perfect murder. He killed his wife with a black widow spider.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Oh, shut up, Buddy.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Daddy says Rose is calm as lettuce. Do you believe that, Doll?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: It's pitiful. Neither one of them know.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I think Daddy suspects.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: No, he doesn't. Not really.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: It's really pitiful. She's in bad shape.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: She's watching the car again?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I get so irritated with Daddy. He's so dumb sometimes.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: There goes Mother.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Let's go peep from the living room.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I think she's gonna kiss him.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: At least.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I can't see. What are they doing, what's happening?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: They're discussing it.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: I can't see, let me see...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: This is my place and you can't have it.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Ohhh-hh... what's happening now?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: He's trying to get up -- good God, one of her titties is out!

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Let me see!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Now I can't see. What are they doing?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Boy! Wow!

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Wow! Brrrother!

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What are they doing?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Buddy, this is amazing, you wouldn't believe it.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: What are they doing, Doll?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: He kissed her.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Is that all?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: He had his hand on her titty.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Let me look.  Aww-rr...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: She's putting the titty back.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Buddy, that was my place.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Buddy, that was pretty snotty of you, pushing me away like that just when it was interesting.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: You shouldn't watch such things, Doll.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Wasn't Daddy wonderful? He wanted to kiss her some more and play with her, but he didn't, because he loves Mother and all of us, and he loves Rose, too. Isn't he wonderful, isn't he great?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Wonderful? He kissed her and played with her titty, and I don't see anything so great about that. He was probably afraid Mother would come back early and catch him.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: You know, Buddy, sometimes you make me sick.
